Originally used for the representation of blood donation, and displayed with blood in the barrel. In 2021 many platforms are switching to a more general-purpose empty syringe. Google and Facebook’s designs previously featured green liquids.

Title: Adhesive Bandage
Description: An adhesive bandage used for first aid. Sometimes called a Band-Aid or band aid after the trademarked product. Sometimes called a plaster .

Title: Crutch
Description: A basic crutch made of metal and rubber.

Title: Stethoscope
Description: A stethoscope with a round resonator and two earpieces. Shown in black, blue, green, or red, depending on the platform.

Title: X-Ray
Description: An x-ray image. May be used to talk about x-rays or medicine in general.

Title: Door
Description: A door, as to the entrance of a room, house , or new opportunity. (We’ll see ourselves out 🚪🚶) Depicted in brown, as made of wood, with a gold handle. May represent literal doors and related concepts (e.g., rooms, houses) but often used figuratively (e.g., opening or closing metaphorical doors). Microsoft’s design previously featured a step, as if a front door. Google’s design previously featured a peephole.

Title: Mirror
Description: A mirror with an ornate gold or silver frame. The shape and style of the mirror varies from platform to platform. Used to talk about mirrors, reflection, or self-reflection.

Title: Window
Description: A square or rectangular window with glass panes. Most platforms show a wooden frame with two or four panels. Used to talk about actual windows or metaphorical windows, which often represent opportunities, perspectives, or unique points of view.

Title: Bed
Description: A bed, made up for sleeping in a house , hotel , or other sleeping accommodation . Shown with a headboard at the left, footboard, mattress, pillow, and sheet. Most platforms suggest a wooden frame and feature blue or red sheets. Commonly used for various content concerning beds, furniture, and housing as well as sleeping , relaxing, and other bedroom activities. Vendors implement the same style of bed for 🛌 Person in Bed , but without a sleeper under the covers.

Title: Couch and Lamp
Description: A couch (sofa) with a floor lamp on the right, as in the living room of a house . Color and style of the couch and lamp vary widely by platform. Used for various content concerning furniture and housing as well as resting and lounging.

Title: Chair
Description: A simple wooden chair. Distinct from 💺 Seat , which is generally depicted as a fixed plane, train, or bus seat, as opposed to a chair which can be moved. May have sexual connotations (e.g., sit on my face ). In 2021 this emoji was also used on TikTok to signify laughter or approval or to create confusion for people not in the know. Learn more here.

Title: Toilet
Description: A white toilet, as used to deposit a 💩 Pile of Poo . (Don’t forget the 🧻 Roll of Paper . ) Most platforms depict a porcelain toilet in profile, bowl facing to the left. Commonly used for various content concerning going to the bathroom or bathrooms more generally. May also be used figuratively, e.g., down the toilet . Google, Microsoft, and Twitter’s designs left the seat up.

Title: Plunger
Description: A toilet plunger with a wooden handle and red flange and cup. Used to talk about toilets and clogged pipes. Also used metaphorically to talk about a mess or something that's disgusting.

Title: Shower
Description: A silver shower head, streaming water to the left. Pressure level varies across platforms. 🧼 Soap not provided. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and water. Shower heads are also featured in 🛁 Bathtub and 🛀 Person Taking a Bath .

Title: Bathtub
Description: A white bathtub with a silver shower head. Often depicted as a cast-iron tub with claw-foot legs. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and bathrooms more generally. Several platforms, including Apple and Facebook, feature soap bubbles or suds. Samsung’s design displays streaming water from the shower head. Vendors implement 🛀 Person Taking a Bath with the same or a similar emoji, but with a person soaking in the tub.

Title: Mouse Trap
Description: A trap used to catch a mouse , rat , or other unwanted rodent. Metaphorically used in emoji form to suggest any kind of trap or entrapment. The style of trap shown on major platforms has a box held high with a single stick. A wedge of cheese is used to lure a mouse into the box, knocking the stick away and trapping — but not killing — the mouse. This is distinct from other traps which kill or injure upon capture.

Title: Razor
Description: A safety razor, depicted in various colors across platforms. Previously shown as a straight razor by Microsoft , WhatsApp , and JoyPixels .

Title: Lotion Bottle
Description: A bottle of lotion for the skin, such as moisturizer or sunscreen (sunblock). May be used for other hygienic liquids, including shampoo and body wash , as well as beauty products. Appearance varies across platforms, but commonly depicted in white and gold colors. Some designs also include a droplet icon on the bottle. Most platforms feature a bottle with a pump, though others previously displayed a cylinder with a cap.

Title: Safety Pin
Description: A silver safety pin or clip, as used to fasten fabric. Generally shown clasped at a 45° angle, with its spring at the lower left. May be used for various content concerning arts, crafts, and sewing. Not to be confused with 📎 Paperclip .

Title: Broom
Description: A traditional broom, as used for sweeping—or ridden by a witch . Shown at a 45° angle, with a wooden handle and yellow bristles at the lower left. Commonly used for various content concerning cleaning, brushing, and figurative sweeps (e.g., in sports or awards). Not to be confused with 🖌️ Paintbrush .

Title: Basket
Description: A basket, as used for storing or carrying such things as food or clothes. Appearance widely varies across platforms but generally depicted as woven from wicker with one or more handles. Commonly used to represent doing laundry or having a picnic. Apple and WhatsApp’s designs, featuring a white cloth, suggest a bread or picnic basket. Samsung’s design displays green fabric, as knitted from yarn . Microsoft’s design previously suggested a laundry basket by holding a blue garment or cloth. Not to be confused with 🗑️ Wastebasket .

Title: Roll of Paper
Description: A roll of paper, as toilet paper (toilet tissue). May also be a roll of kitchen/paper towels. Depicted at various angles, with a sheet unfurling. Commonly used for toilet paper but may also be used for various content concerning toilets , going to the bathroom, bathrooms, cleaning, or paper more generally.

Title: Bucket
Description: A blue or green bucket or pail. Used to talk about real or metaphorical buckets. May be used to talk about bucket lists, kicking the bucket, making baskets in basketball, an abundance of something (like rain or money), and many other contexts.

Title: Soap
Description: A bar of soap, as used in the shower , bath or for hand washing. Generally shown with lathered bubbles. Depicted in various colors, often pink, and at different angles. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning. May be used to represent the opposite of dirt or being dirty. Recommended for use to prevent the spread of COVID-19 .

Title: Bubbles
Description: A few floating bubbles. May be used to represent soap suds, carbonation, or an effervescent personality.

Title: Toothbrush
Description: A brightly colored plastic toothbrush with white bristles. Used to talk about oral hygiene, daily routines, or something that is fresh and clean.

Title: Sponge
Description: A peanut -shaped sponge, as used for cleaning or bathing. Generally depicted in yellow and at different angles across platforms. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning.

Title: Fire Extinguisher
Description: A fire extinguisher, as used to put out small fires . Depicted as a red tank with a black hose and pressure gauge. Most platforms include an image of a flame on a white label. Commonly used for various content concerning fire safety, emergencies, and literal and figurative fires.

Title: Shopping Cart
Description: A metal shopping cart that you might find in a supermarket or grocery store. The color of the cart's wheels and handle vary by platform. Previous Google designs displayed the cart itself as yellow and orange , while Facebook's cart is red. Most popular around Black Friday and into the Christmas season.

Title: Love Letter
Description: The back of an envelope , generally shown in white and sealed with a red heart . Represents a love letter or note, valentine , or affectionate greeting card. Commonly used to convey various feelings or messages of love and happiness. Facebook’s envelope is pink, while Microsoft’s envelope was previously open.

Title: Heart with Arrow
Description: A heart emoji with an arrow through the center, like the arrow that cupid shoots for love. This emoji tends to spike in popularity on Valentine's Day .

Title: Heart with Ribbon
Description: A heart-shaped box, tied with a ribbon . May be a gift box, box of chocolates, or a jewellery box.

Title: Sparkling Heart
Description: A pink love heart with stars around it, making it look like it is sparkling or shimmering. This emoji tends to spike in popularity on Valentine's Day .

Title: Growing Heart
Description: A pink heart, inside a slightly larger pink heart, inside a larger-again pink heart. Intended to give the impression of a heart increasing in size. This emoji tends to spike in popularity on Valentine's Day . An early Apple design displayed as a plain Pink Heart .

Title: Beating Heart
Description: A heart with vibration/movement lines above it or around it, indicating it is beating. Displayed in pink or red on most platforms. An early version of this emoji on iOS had the same design as 💖 Sparkling Heart .

Title: Revolving Hearts
Description: Hearts revolving around one or more other hearts. This emoji was originally animated on a number of Japanese devices. Apple’s artwork for this emoji shows two hearts switching places, with a circular line simulating the action this would make. Google’s artwork previously displayed five hearts in a circle-like shape .

Title: Two Hearts
Description: Two pink love hearts. One larger than the other. Can be used to display that “love is in the air”. This emoji tends to spike in popularity on Valentine's Day . On Snapchat , this emoji next to a contact denotes that you have been #1 BFs with each other for two consecutive months. A bug in October 2019 has a yellow heart emoji showing instead of 💕 for some Snapchat users .

Title: Heart Decoration
Description: A decorative heart that generally displays as a white heart-shaped cutout in a pink or purple roundrect. Google previously displayed a pink heart with yellow dots around it, Samsung’s was a pink patterned heart , and Microsoft’s had corner stitches .

Title: Heart Exclamation
Description: A decorative exclamation mark , where a heart forms the top part of the symbol, and a circle the lower part. Similar to the way to the man in business suit levitating also creates a similar shape.

Title: Broken Heart
Description: A love heart, broken in two. This emoji represents the aching one feels when they are missing the person they love.

Title: Heart on Fire
Description: A heart shown on fire, for extreme or passionate forms of love or lust. Most representative of desire or lust, this emoji may also indicate a sense of burning a past love and moving on.

Title: Red Heart
Description: A classic red love heart emoji. The red heart ideograph is traditionally used for expressions of love and romance across many cultures, with this being amongst the most frequence use cases for this emoji. However, the Red Heart emoji is also often used to express non-romantic positive sentiments, in part thanks to its use as one of the default reaction emoji options across many social messaging platforms (e.g. Instagram , Slack , WhatsApp ). Additionally, as with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. This is historically the most popular heart emoji by a considerable distance and is amongst the most popular emojis of all time. A similar emoji exists for the heart suit in a deck of playing cards. On Snapchat , this emoji displays next to a friend when you have been #1 BFs with each other for two consecutive weeks. Note: the Unicode Character Database (UCD) name “Heavy Black Heart” pre-dates color emoji, when the term referred to a solid, black ❤︎ heart character. See the glossary for information on the term black in historic Unicode character names.

Title: Pink Heart
Description: A plain pink heart, expected to be frequently used alongside other hearts . Used to represent love, friendship, and feelings of warmth, and the color pink. For many years before its introduction in 2022 , the plain pink heart was one of the world's most frequently requested emojis. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. On several platforms, pink hearts are used in the design of other emojis. These emoji include: Sparkling Heart 💖 , Two Hearts 💕 , Growing Heart 💗 , Beating Heart 💓 , Revolving Heart 💞 , Heart with Arrow 💘 , Heart with Ribbon 💝 , and Kiss 💏 .

Title: Orange Heart
Description: An orange heart emoji, often used alongside other colored hearts . As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Yellow Heart
Description: A yellow or gold colored heart, frequently used alongside other colored hearts . Amusingly, this emoji displayed as a pink hairy heart on Android 4.4. It has been suggested that this visual oddity was created following a misinterpretation of Unicode's black-and-white reference images. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. On Snapchat , this emoji next to a contact denotes a person that you snap the most, and who also snaps you the most ( #1 best friend ). The yellow #1 BF heart turns into a red heart after two weeks.

Title: Green Heart
Description: A green heart emoji, often used alongside other colored hearts . As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. For example, this emoji is frequently used on Twitter/X in reference to the Korean boy band NCT . Shown with beads of sweat on an orange and pink heart in previous versions of Android .

Title: Blue Heart
Description: A blue heart emoji, commonly used by brands as a neutral heart color. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. Can also be used to discuss someone passing away, though this use case is more explicitly associated with the 🤍 White Heart . An early Google design of this emoji depicted the heart as if it were made out of gemstone .

Title: Light Blue Heart
Description: A light blue heart, frequently used alongside other hearts . As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Purple Heart
Description: A purple heart emoji, often used alongside other colored hearts . As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. For example, this emoji is frequently used on Twitter/X in reference to the Korean boy band Bangtan Sonyeondan , more commonly known as BTS. Previously shown as a pink heart in Android 4.4 .

Title: Brown Heart
Description: A brown heart emoji. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. For example, this emoji has been found to often be used to discuss topics related to racial identity . As of February 2021 , this emoji was the least used of the nine colored hearts that existed at that time (the others being ❤️ , 🧡 , 💛 , 💚 , 💙 , 💜 , 🖤 , and 🤍 ).

Title: Black Heart
Description: A heart shaded completely black. May be used to express morbidity, sorrow, or a form of dark humor, but despite the color remains most commonly used for love and affection . Additionally, as with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Grey Heart
Description: A grey heart emoji. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: White Heart
Description: A white heart emoji, used for love and affection. Also commonly used to discuss someone passing away . As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji can also often used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. An alternative character known as White Heart Suit is also available, but not intended to have an emoji appearance.

Title: Kiss Mark
Description: The mark left after a firm kiss is placed with bright lipstick. Used in place of ‘xxx’ (kisses), or to send a kiss to someone. More seductive than the kiss emoji.

Title: Hundred Points
Description: 100 emoji: the number one-hundred, written in red, underlined twice for emphasis. Originating from the number 100 written on a school exam or paper to indicate a perfect score of 100 out of 100.  Teachers in Japan may also use a stamp in addition to the 100 mark, to indicate that a student has performed very well. This 100 emoji is commonly used as a shorthand for 100% , with the usage meaning “keep it real” or a similar sentiment. A 100 emoji can be used to express pride or general acceptance of an idea. In Snapchat , the 100 emoji appearing next to a fire emoji indicates a 100 day Snapstreak.

Title: Anger Symbol
Description: A red symbol found in Anime/Manga and used to represent the veins popping on a very angry person. Also used in other comic books to indicate a punch landed, perhaps next to the words “Bam” or “Pow”.

Title: Collision
Description: A cartoon-styled representation of a collision. Depicted as a star-like, orange-and-yellow fiery burst, generally with one point extending to the bottom right, as if from the source of the collision. May be used to represent various types of bangs, explosions, or crashes. Like 🔥 Fire and 💯 Hundred Points , commonly used to represent something is excellent or exciting in some way. Apple implements a version of 💥 Collision in its 🧨 Firecracker and 📸 Camera With Flash .

Title: Sweat Droplets
Description: Three, light blue droplets, as sweat beads, splashing down to the right. Resembles plewds , stylized sweat droplets used in comics and animation to show characters working hard or feeling stressed. May be used to represent various types of liquids, including sexual fluids. May also be used to represent various liquid-based slang expressions (e.g., drip , “exceptional style, swagger"). Not to be confused with 💧 Droplet , though their applications may overlap. Google , Microsoft , and Samsung's design previously featured two, upwardly directed droplets.

Title: Dashing Away
Description: A cartoon-styled gust of air. Depicted as a small, gray cloud with motion lines, rushing to the left. Resembles briffits , a stylized cloud of dust used in comics and animation to indicate someone or something has dashed away (e.g., leaving someone in the dust ). May be used to represent speed, smoking, and various types of wind, blown or broken. May precede other emoji, such as 🏃Runner or 🚗 Automobile , to indicate something is fast or fleeing: 🏃💨, 🚗💨. Not to be confused 🌬️ Wind Face , though their applications may overlap.

Title: Hole
Description: A round, black, cartoon-styled hole, as a manhole or a hole (cup) in golf . May be used to represent various types of literal or figurative holes, e.g., black holes, rabbit holes.

Title: Speech Balloon
Description: A cartoon-style balloon used to represent spoken word in comics. Sometimes  used in communication apps to indicate that another person is typing a message.

Title: Eye in Speech Bubble
Description: A speech bubble showing an eye inside. When using text-to-speech on Apple platforms, this emoji is read aloud as: "Eye in speech bubble representing anti-bullying campaign". This emoji was released in conjunction with the Ad Council for the I Am A Witness campaign.

Title: Left Speech Bubble
Description: A left-facing speech bubble, which was included in Unicode 7.0, but not considered a standard addition for the purposes of emoji presentation.

Title: Right Anger Bubble
Description: A form of speech balloon used with angular edges, used to denote angry speech in comics.

Title: Thought Balloon
Description: A large cloud-like shape more commonly known as a thought bubble. Used to represent thinking, or thoughts, and commonly used in comics to display the thoughts of a drawn character. May also be used to represent a dream, or daydream.

Title: Zzz
Description: A series of three Zs making a Zzz. Represents sleeping, snoring, dreaming, or any sleep-related state. Can also be used in some contexts to represent something that is boring.

Title: Red Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of red. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Orange Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of orange. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Yellow Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of yellow. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Green Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of green. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Blue Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of blue. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Purple Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of purple. May be used to represent anything purple. During 2024 this emoji began to be used by French users of social media platforms to reference a term for a serious form of assault. This was due to its phonetic similarity to the color purple within the French language. Additionally, as with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Brown Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of brown. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Black Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of black. May be used to represent anything black.

Title: White Circle
Description: A circle shown in the color of white. May be used to represent anything white.

Title: Red Square
Description: A square shown in the color red. May be used to represent anything red, including a red penalty card in football (soccer).

Title: Orange Square
Description: A square shown in the color of orange. May be used to represent anything orange.

Title: Yellow Square
Description: A square shown in the color yellow. When players of the word game Wordle share their results on social platforms the results are represented through a series of green , yellow, and black or white square emojis. This emoji indicates that the player guessed a correct letter but in the wrong place within the word. This emoji is also often used to represent a y ellow penalty card in football (soccer) . Additionally, as with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

Title: Green Square
Description: A square shown in the color of green. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts ), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. When players of the word game Wordle share their results on social platforms the results are represented through a series of green, yellow , and black or white square emojis. This emoji indicates that the player guessed a correct letter in its right place. Additionally, in May 2021, this emoji was occasionally shown in X/Twitter names in support of Taproot , a Bitcoin fork (potential feature change) that would allow additional privacy measures for transactions.

Title: Blue Square
Description: A square shown in the color of blue. May be used to represent anything blue.

Title: Purple Square
Description: A square shown in the color of purple. May be used to represent anything purple.

Title: Brown Square
Description: A square shown in the color of brown. May be used to represent anything brown.

Title: Black Large Square
Description: A square shown in the shade of black. May be used to represent anything black. When players of the word game Wordle share their results on social platforms the results are represented through a series of green , yellow , and black or white square emojis. This emoji can indicate that the player guessed an incorrect letter, i.e. a letter that is not present within the word.

Title: White Large Square
Description: A square shown in the shade of white. May be used to represent anything white. When players of the word game Wordle share their results on social platforms the results are represented through a series of green , yellow , and black or white square emojis. This emoji can indicate that the player guessed an incorrect letter, i.e. a letter that is not present within the word.

Title: Black Medium Square
Description: A medium-sized square shaded completely black. Smaller than the ⬛ Black Large Square and larger than the ◾ Black Medium-Small Square and the ▪️ Black Small Square.

Title: White Medium Square
Description: A medium-sized square shaded completely white. Smaller than the White Large Square and larger than the White Medium-Small Square and the White Small Square .

Title: Black Medium-Small Square
Description: A medium-small-sized square shaded completely black. Smaller than the ⬛ Black Large Square and ◾ Black Medium-Small Square but larger than the ▪️ Black Small Square.

Title: Black Small Square
Description: A very small square shaded completely black. Notably smaller than the ⬛ Black Large Square , ◼️ Black Medium Square , and the ◾ Black Medium-Small Square .

Title: White Small Square
Description: A medium-small-sized square shaded completely white. Smaller than the White Large Square , White Medium Square , and the White Medium-Small Square .

Title: Large Orange Diamond
Description: A larger version of the small orange diamond emoji.

Title: Large Blue Diamond
Description: A large version of the small blue diamond emoji. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here .

Title: Small Blue Diamond
Description: A small version of the large blue diamond emoji. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here .

Title: Red Triangle Pointed Up
Description: A small red equilateral triangle, pointing upwards.

Title: Red Triangle Pointed Down
Description: A small red equilateral triangle, pointing downwards. During 2024 this emoji was restricted on Meta platforms Facebook , Instagram , and WhatsApp .

Title: Diamond with a Dot
Description: A glyph that is used for kawaii in Japan, resembling the shape of a flower. Google's design previously resembled a flower , while Samsung's previously displayed a white symbol on a blue square. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here .

Title: Radio Button
Description: A radio button user interface element, used in form fields with two or more choices. Differs from a checkbox , in that only one response can be selected. This emoji generally shows the on/enabled state for the radio button, with a smaller circle inside a larger outer circle. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here .

Title: White Square Button
Description: The inverse of the 🔲 Black Square Button .

Title: Black Square Button
Description: A square version of the 🔘 Radio Button emoji. The inverse of the 🔳 White Square Button .

Title: Elevator
Description: A symbol showing two or three people standing in a square with up and down arrows above them. Most platforms feature a simple blue and white design. Mostly used to talk about elevators. Also used metaphorically to talk about moving or leveling up or down.

Title: ATM Sign
Description: A square symbol showing the letter "ATM", standing for "Automated Teller Machine".

Title: Litter in Bin Sign
Description: A symbol showing a person putting litter (rubbish) in the trash (rubbish bin). A more positive version of the Do Not Litter Symbol .

Title: Potable Water
Description: A symbol for potable (drinkable) water, usually shown with a faucet filling a drinking glass. Commonly used for various content concerning water, drinking, thirst, and dripping. Some platforms, including Apple and WhatsApp, depict the emoji as an object while others feature a stylized, white faucet on a blue square, as a sign or icon of water that is safe to drink. Compare 🚱 Non-Potable Water , which indicates water that is not safe to drink. Apple's design previously featured a blue symbol design, Microsoft's a cup filled with water.

Title: Wheelchair Symbol
Description: The international symbol of access, used to denote a facility which has been designed with accessibility or people in wheelchairs in mind. Appears as a blue sign, with a white graphic of a person sitting in a wheelchair. Many platforms now use the Accessible Icon Project style image for this emoji, which displays the person in the wheelchair in a more active position.

Title: Men’s Room
Description: A stick-figure icon of a man, generally used to indicate a male restroom . The female equivalent is the Womens Symbol emoji.

Title: Women’s Room
Description: A stick-figure icon of a woman, generally used to indicate a female restroom . The male equivalent is the Mens Symbol emoji.

Title: Restroom
Description: A restroom symbol, depicting a iconography of a man and woman . Used to indicate the location of public bathrooms / toilets / restrooms. Used as an alternative to the water closet symbol.

Title: Baby Symbol
Description: The symbol for a baby, usually used to indicate a room that is suitable to change a baby in. Often located in or near public restrooms.

Title: Water Closet
Description: A water closet is a name used for public toilet, bathroom or restroom used in some countries. Typically abbreviated to the letters WC, this may be found on signage in public buildings, as an alternative to the restroom symbol.

Title: Passport Control
Description: A person checking passports at an international border.

Title: Customs
Description: A customs officer inspecting luggage . May be shown on signage at airports or other border crossings. Not to be confused with the passport control emoji .

Title: Left Luggage
Description: An icon representing a place to leave luggage. Most commonly found at Japanese train stations to signify coin lockers where bags can be stored for a daily fee. This emoji displays a suitcase with a key above or below it, ususually in blue.

Title: Warning
Description: A triangle with an exclamation mark inside, used as a warning or alert. This emoji is used prominently within social media platform BeReal's core time-sensitive "⚠️ Time to BeReal ⚠️" push notification. This notification is shown when being prompted to share a photo of themselves and their immediate surroundings, with this notification given within a randomly selected two-minute window every day.

Title: Children Crossing
Description: A crossing sign for children, usually positioned near schools or other areas that drivers should be cautious of young children in the area.

Title: No Entry
Description: A red circle with a straight horizontal line across its center. Used on signs to indicate that entry into the area where the sign is displayed is forbidden.

Title: Prohibited
Description: A red circle with a diagonal line through the middle, from top-left to bottom right, used to indicate that something is not permitted Commonly shown in conjunction with other symbols to indicate No Smoking , No Bikes , or similar.

Title: No Bicycles
Description: A bicycle with a red stroke through it, indicating that bikes are prohibited from this location. May be seen in pedestrian malls with a bicycle restriction or crossing train tracks in some countries.

Title: No Smoking
Description: A lit cigarette with a red stroke through it, indicating that smoking is prohibited in this location.

Title: No Littering
Description: A person dropping litter (rubbish, trash) with a red stroke through it, indicating that littering is prohibited in this area. Usually implied by the fact that littering is not welcome anywhere, this sign serves as a reminder in areas that are known to attract litter.

Title: Non-Potable Water
Description: A water tap with a red stroke through it, indicating that water is not safe for drinking (non-potable). May be used at a camp site or other area that has water suitable for cleaning or other non-drinking purposes.

Title: No Pedestrians
Description: A pedestrian symbol with a red stroke through it, indicating that pedestrians are prohibited from this location. May be seen in dedicated bike lanes, highways, or other areas not suitable to be on-foot.

Title: No Mobile Phones
Description: A mobile phone with a red stroke through it, indicating that mobile phones should not be present. Often seen in restricted areas, such as Customs or Passport Control .

Title: No One Under Eighteen
Description: The number eighteen with a red stroke through it, indicating a location where a person must be aged 18 or above to enter. Often used online to indicate adult or NSFW content. Google's design includes the text "under" above the number eighteen. The Samsung version of this emoji previously displayed the number 19 . This may have been due to the practice of counting the first year of life as one instead of zero in parts of East Asia such as South Korea (the location of the Samsung Headquarters).

Title: Radioactive
Description: A hazard symbol for radiation or radioactivity. May appear similar to a three-pronged fan at small sizes. Generally displayed on an orange or yellow background.

Title: Biohazard
Description: A hazard symbol used in the labeling of biological materials that carry a significant health risk, including viral and bacteriological samples. Generally displayed on an orange or yellow background.

Title: Up Arrow
Description: An arrow, pointing up. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Title: Up-Right Arrow
Description: An arrow pointing diagonally in an up-right, or north-east direction.

Title: Right Arrow
Description: An arrow, pointing right. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Title: Down-Right Arrow
Description: An arrow pointing diagonally in an down-right, or south-east direction.

Title: Down Arrow
Description: An arrow, pointing down. Generally used to highlight a piece of content placed below where this emoji can be used. This content could be a picture, a website link, or a different piece of text, See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Title: Down-Left Arrow
Description: An arrow pointing diagonally in an down-left, or south-west direction.

Title: Left Arrow
Description: An arrow, pointing left. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Title: Up-Left Arrow
Description: An arrow pointing diagonally in an up-left, or north-west direction.

Title: Up-Down Arrow
Description: A vertical line with arrowheads on both ends, pointing up and down.

Title: Left-Right Arrow
Description: A horizontal line with arrowheads on both ends, pointing left and right.

Title: Right Arrow Curving Left
Description: An arrow pointing to the left, with a curved hook at the other end. Similar in appearance to a sideways U Turn symbol, or a reply icon in an email application.

Title: Left Arrow Curving Right
Description: An arrow pointing to the right, with a curved hook at the other end. Similar in appearance to a sideways U Turn symbol, or a forward icon in an email application.

Title: Right Arrow Curving Up
Description: A curved arrow pointing up.

Title: Right Arrow Curving Down
Description: A curved arrow pointing down. Generally used to highlight a piece of content placed below where this emoji can be used. This content could be a picture, a website link, or a different piece of text,

Title: Clockwise Vertical Arrows
Description: Circular arrows pointing in an anticlockwise direction. Similar to symbols sometimes used for refresh or rotate .

Title: Counterclockwise Arrows Button
Description: Two arrows forming a circle, pointing in an anticlockwise direction. Similar to symbols sometimes used for refresh or rotate . May also be used to indicate a task is in progress. Previously showed in a clockwise direction on Windows.

Title: Back Arrow
Description: The word "back" with an arrow above it, pointing to the left.

Title: End Arrow
Description: The word "end" with an arrow above it, pointing to the left.

Title: On! Arrow
Description: The capitalized word "on" followed by an exclamation mark (!) with a double-sided arrow above it.

Title: Soon Arrow
Description: The word "soon" with an arrow above it, pointing to the right.

Title: Top Arrow
Description: The word "top" with an arrow pointing up above it.

Title: Shuffle Tracks Button
Description: Two arrows pointing right while crossing over one another. Used to indicate putting music on shuffle: randomizing the order of tracks in the upcoming playlist. May also be used to indicate two items switching places.

Title: Repeat Button
Description: Circular arrows pointing in a clockwise direction. Used in music player applications to loop a track or album continuously. Commonly used to repesent a retweet on Twitter.

Title: Repeat Single Button
Description: Arrows pointing in a clockwise direction, with a number 1 badge in the lower corner.  Used in music player applications to loop a track or album once.

Title: Play Button
Description: A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing right. Commonly used as a symbol for play. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Title: Fast-Forward Button
Description: Two triangles pointing to the right. Most commonly used as a symbol for fast forwarding media such as video tapes , CDs , or digital audio and video.

Title: Next Track Button
Description: A symbol used in media players to indicate skipping to the next track (or scene). Shown as two triangles pointing right followed by a vertical bar.

Title: Play or Pause Button
Description: A play-pause icon, showing a right-pointing triangle (play) next to a double vertical bar (pause).

Title: Reverse Button
Description: A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing left. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Title: Last Track Button
Description: A symbol used in media players to indicate skipping to the first or previous track (or scene). Shown as a vertical bar followed by two triangles pointing left.

Title: Upwards Button
Description: A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing up. Styled similarly to the left and right triangles and colored as either gray or blue, but shown in orange on Android. Previously displayed as red on Windows .

Title: Fast Up Button
Description: Two triangles pointing up. Similar to rewind icon, rotated 90° clockwise.

Title: Downwards Button
Description: A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing down. Styled similarly to the left and right pointing triangles and colored as either gray or blue, but shown in orange on Android. Previously displayed as red on Windows .

Title: Fast Down Button
Description: Two triangles pointing down. Similar to rewind icon, rotated 90° counter-clockwise.

Title: Pause Button
Description: A pause icon, displayed as two vertical bars.

Title: Stop Button
Description: A stop icon, displayed as a square.

Title: Record Button
Description: A record icon, displayed as a circle.

Title: Eject Button
Description: An eject symbol, displayed as an upward-pointing triangle above a horiztonal bar. May be used as a physical button or an icon in a user interface. Represents the action of ejecting physical media such as a floppy disk , videocasette or DVD on a computer or media player.

Title: Cinema
Description: An emoji representing the cinema: a large screen showing the latest movies, available to the public. Displayed by most platforms as a film projector symbol, and previously by Google and Microsoft as a cinema screen with curtains.

Title: Dim Button
Description: An icon of a outlined sun, used when decreasing the brightness of a screen. Appears smaller than the High Brightness Symbol .

Title: Bright Button
Description: An icon of a outlined sun, used when increasing the brightness of a screen. Appears larger than the Low Brightness Symbol .

Title: Antenna Bars
Description: Bars increasing in height, showing the strength of the mobile (cellular) phone signal. More bars signifies better reception.

Title: Vibration Mode
Description: An icon representing vibration mode on a mobile phone , indicating that a phone should be switched to silent and/or vibrate mode. Displayed as a phone with either zig-zag lines or muted-bell icon on most platforms. Early versions of this emoji often used a heart alongside a mobile phone , as commonly seen in Japan .

Title: Mobile Phone Off
Description: A sign indicating that mobile phones should be turned off. Used in situations such as a cinema or live performance. Displayed as a mobile phone with the word OFF. Previously shown with a cross instead of the word OFF on Windows .

Title: Place of Worship
Description: A building used for worship by people of any faith or religion. Examples include a church , mosque , or synagogue . A person is shown on their knees praying, in this symbol. Multi-faith places of worship are commonly found at airports .

Title: Om
Description: A symbol often used in relation to the religions of Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism and Jainism.

Title: Star of David
Description: A symbol often used in relation to the religion of Judaism. Not to be confused with the Six Pointed Star With Middle Dot emoji .

Title: Wheel of Dharma
Description: A symbol often used in relation to the Indian religions of Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism and Jainism.

Title: Yin Yang
Description: The circular symbol frequently used to represent the concepts of yin and yang (also yinyang or yin-yang). The yin and yang symbol (or taijitu) shows a balance between two opposite but interconnected forces with a portion of the opposite element in each section.

Title: Latin Cross
Description: A latin cross, otherwise known as a Christian cross. This cross symbol is often used as a symbol of Christianity. Similar in appearance to the Orthodox cross .

Title: Orthodox Cross
Description: An orthodox cross symbol, also known as a Russian Orthodox cross or Byzantine cross.

Title: Star and Crescent
Description: The crescent moon and star is a symbol often associated with the religion of Islam. This symbol can be found on the flags of many countries, such as Algeria , Azerbaijan , Malaysia , Pakistan and Turkey .

Title: Peace Symbol
Description: A circular symbol, commonly used as a representation of peace. Alternatives include the Victory Hand , or the Dove of Peace .

Title: Menorah
Description: A menorah showing nine lit candles, used on the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah .

Title: Dotted Six-Pointed Star
Description: A star with six points, and a dot in the center. Similar to the Star of David emoji .

Title: Khanda
Description: The Khanda, the symbol of the Sikhism.

Title: Aries
Description: The Aries astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Ram.

Title: Taurus
Description: The Taurus astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Bull.

Title: Gemini
Description: The Gemini astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents Twins.

Title: Cancer
Description: The Cancer astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Crab.

Title: Leo
Description: The Leo astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Lion.

Title: Virgo
Description: The Virgo astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Maiden.

Title: Libra
Description: The Libra astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents weighing scales .

Title: Scorpio
Description: The Scorpius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Scorpion.

Title: Sagittarius
Description: The Sagittarius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents an Archer.

Title: Capricorn
Description: The Capricorn astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Goat.

Title: Aquarius
Description: The Aquarius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Water-bearer.

Title: Pisces
Description: The Pisces astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Fish.

Title: Ophiuchus
Description: Ophiuchus is used by some as a 13th sign in the Zodiac. The symbol for ophiuchus appears a U shape with a wavy line through it.

Title: Female Sign
Description: A circle shown with a crossed vertical line beneath it, used as a representation for women. Often used on International Women's Day .

Title: Transgender Symbol
Description: A symbol commonly used to represent those in the transgender community. Used within the draft emoji sequence for the Transgender Flag emoji , and also given emoji presentation on Samsung devices. Shows as a plain text character on other platforms.

Title: Plus
Description: A large plus / addition symbol, as used in mathematics.

Title: Minus
Description: A large minus symbol, as used in mathematics.

Title: Divide
Description: A large division symbol, as used in mathematics.

Title: Heavy Equals Sign
Description: An equals sign in the style of the already existing set of mathematical symbols ✖️ Multiply , ➕ Plus , ➖ Minus , and ➗ Divide .

Title: Infinity
Description: The symbol for infinity enclosed within a circle or square. Originally encoded as a symbol to represent acid-free paper , this permanent paper sign was later given emoji presentation to form an infinity emoji. May also be used by members of the autism rights movement to represent neurodiversity. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here .

Title: Exclamation Question Mark
Description: A large red exclamation mark (!) and a large red question mark symbol (?) placed side-by-side (!?).

Title: Red Question Mark
Description: A large red question mark (?) symbol emoji.

Title: White Question Mark
Description: A large white question mark (?) symbol emoji.

Title: White Exclamation Mark
Description: A large white exclamation mark (!) symbol emoji.

Title: Red Exclamation Mark
Description: A large red exclamation mark (!) symbol emoji.

Title: Wavy Dash
Description: Just like a regular dash (hyphen), sometimes used in Asian character sets in the same way a – or — is used in latin character sets.

Title: Currency Exchange
Description: A symbol for exchanging of two currencies. Most commonly displayed as a dollar symbol , with arrows to and from a yen symbol . Google and Samsung's designs previously showed banknotes and coins in yen , dollars , euros and pounds .

Title: Heavy Dollar Sign
Description: A large dollar sign ($), which can be used to represent various international currencies. Generally depicted in either black or green.

Title: Keycap Number Sign
Description: A hash key, sometimes referred to as a pound key in the United States. Most commonly used online to make a hashtag (or hash flag ) on social media sites.

Title: Keycap Asterisk
Description: The asterisk symbol (*) on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit Zero
Description: The number 0 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit One
Description: The number 1 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit Two
Description: The number 2 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit Three
Description: The number 3 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit Four
Description: The number 4 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit Six
Description: The number 6 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit Seven
Description: The number 7 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap Digit Eight
Description: The number 8 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Keycap: 10
Description: The number 10 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Title: Input Latin Uppercase
Description: A symbol showing the capital letters A, B, C and D. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to toggle capital letter input.

Title: Input Latin Lowercase
Description: A symbol showing the lowercase letters a, b, c and d. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to toggle lowercase letter input.

Title: Input Numbers
Description: A symbol showing the numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable numeric input, as opposed to alphabetical or symbol input.

Title: Input Symbols
Description: A symbol showing the following glyphs: 〒 (Japanese postal mark), 𝅘𝅥𝅮 (music note), & (ampersand, or sometimes an @ symbol) and % (percentage sign). Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable symbol input, as opposed to alphabetical or numeric input.

Title: Input Latin Letters
Description: A symbol showing the lowercase letters a, b, c and d. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable alphabetical input, as opposed to numeric or symbol input.

Title: A Button (Blood Type)
Description: A symbol representing Blood Type A. Displayed as the letter A on a red background. Samsung's design for this emoji previously included a blue background instead of a red background.

Title: AB Button (Blood Type)
Description: A symbol representing Blood Type AB. Displayed as the letters AB on a red background. Samsung's design for this emoji previously included a blue background instead of a red background.

Title: B Button (Blood Type)
Description: A symbol representing Blood Type B. Displayed as the letter B on a red background. Sometimes used online to replace the letter C at the start of words in reference to the Bloods street gang's practice of turning words like cool into bool . This has expanded in some instances to starting any word with the letter B, or more specifically, this emoji which makes it more 🅱️lear that a letter has been replaced. Samsung's design for this emoji previously included a blue background instead of a red background.

Title: CL Button
Description: CL is what shows on the CL ear button of some older mobile phones.

Title: Cool Button
Description: The word cool , shown enclosed in a square. This generally displays in a shade of blue, or blue-gray on most platforms. Used as a text decoration.

Title: Free Button
Description: The word free , shown enclosed in a square.

Title: ID Button
Description: The letters ID in a square.

Title: Circled M
Description: The letter M in a circle, commonly used in to identify a Metro (subway, underground train) station in a city area.

Title: New Button
Description: The word new , shown enclosed in a square.

Title: NG Button
Description: The letters NG , shown enclosed in a square, which are an acronym for the words No Good . The origin of NG refers to bloopers shown during or after the credits of a live television show in Japan (known as NGs ), but can be used in any field as a form of shorthand for no good.

Title: O Button (Blood Type)
Description: A symbol representing Blood Type O. Displayed as the letter O on a red background. Samsung's design for this emoji previously included a blue background instead of a red background.

Title: OK Button
Description: The letters OK , shown enclosed in a square. Meaning Okay , denoting approval. The opposite of the Squared NG Emoji .

Title: SOS Button
Description: SOS is the description for the distress signal in Morse Code . This emoji means SOS or “emergency”.

Title: Up! Button
Description: The word up with an exclamation point after it, shown enclosed in a square. Originally intended to denote leveling up in a game.

Title: Vs Button
Description: A square icon with rounded sides containing the letters "VS". Generally depicted as being orange in color. Used to represent a contest between two sides, such as in competitive sports.

Title: Japanese “Here” Button
Description: Means “Here” in Japanese, referring to a destination.

Title: Japanese “Service Charge” Button
Description: Translates as meaning complimentary, or free of charge. For example, a drink that is given "on the house" to a regular customer.

Title: Japanese “Monthly Amount” Button
Description: CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters . Means “moon” or “month” in Chinese.

Title: Japanese “Not Free of Charge” Button
Description: This emoji means to own or posses . CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Reserved” Button
Description: This character translates as meaning a finger or toe pointing to indicate a certain direction. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Bargain” Button
Description: Denotes a “good bargain” in Japanese.

Title: Japanese “Discount” Button
Description: Symbol for a sale, or bargain prices in Japan (“cut prices”). Literally translated, this character means to cut or divide. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Free of Charge” Button
Description: This means to lack , or have none of something. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Prohibited” Button
Description: This Emoji means “prohibit, restrict or forbid” in Japanese. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Acceptable” Button
Description: The 可 (ka) character means to allow, to permit, and to be able to in Japanese.

Title: Japanese “Application” Button
Description: This Emoji has two meanings. One meaning is “request” in Japanese. An alternative meaning is “monkey” in the Chinese zodiac. It is commonly used in Japan to denote an application form or contact information for inquiries. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Passing Grade” Button
Description: Means “agreement” in Japanese. More literally, it means to unite, or join together. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Vacancy” Button
Description: This 空 character means empty and available in Japanese. This is used in the context of an empty parking space or a vacant hotel room. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “Secret” Button
Description: The 秘 character means secret or confidential in Japanese.

Title: Japanese “Open for Business” Button
Description: Means “work” in Japanese.  This Emoji used to mean “open for business” and precedes business hours. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Japanese “No Vacancy” Button
Description: This emoji means “full” in Japanese, usually used to denote “full capacity” such as a gas/petrol tank on a car or pre-paid phone card. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Title: Medical Symbol
Description: A symbol displaying of a rod with a snake entwined around the outside in a downward-spiral shape. Associated with medicine and health care services such as doctors or hospitals. A similar and related symbol called the Caduceus is frequently used in the United States .

Title: Recycling Symbol
Description: The universal recycling symbol, featuring three arrows pointing clockwise in a triangular formation. The word “black” in the official name is due to this emoji existing as a unicode character before the current standardized emoji set.

Title: Fleur-de-lis
Description: A decorative symbol that appears like a golden flower, but found in all manner of logos, symbols, and patterns. This symbol forms part of the World Scout Emblem , amongst other uses.

Title: Name Badge
Description: A name badge, used to identify oneself in a location that others may not know your name, such as a school trip, or a work conference. This tulip -shaped name badge is one of many designs commonly found at kindergartens in Japan.

Title: Japanese Symbol for Beginner
Description: A yellow and green shield symbol, called a Shoshinsha Mark . Must be displayed by drivers in Japan for one year after they receive their drivers licence. Similar to L-Plates used to identify learner drivers in other countries.

Title: Hollow Red Circle
Description: Used as an alternative to a check (tick) in Japan for a something that is correct. The opposite of an X ( cross mark ) for something wrong.

Title: Check Mark Button
Description: A check mark that displays a white outlined appearance. Shows on most platforms with a bright green rounded rectangle or circle surrounding it. Android previously displayed this as an outlined blue check mark / blue tick. This emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, possibly in an attempt to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark.

Title: Check Box with Check
Description: A checkbox showing a check mark inside the box. Not to be confused with the similarly named Ballot Box With Ballot emoji, though Samsung did originally include a ballot box as part of this emoji's design. This emoji is not supported in Twitter names, possibly in an attempt to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark.

Title: Check Mark
Description: A thick check mark / tick displayed on some platforms in a handwritten style. Generally displayed in black. Commonly used in lists to signify completed tasks or verification of a statement of fact. Previously shown in red on Samsung and green on Google and Microsoft . Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here . See also: ✅ Check Mark Button , ☑️ Check Box with Check .

Title: Cross Mark
Description: A large red cross mark, displayed in the shape of a letter X and similar to a multiplication sign .

Title: Cross Mark Button
Description: A cross mark that displays with a white outlined appearance. Shows on most platforms with a bright green rounded rectangle or circle surrounding it.

Title: Curly Loop
Description: A curled loop, which is shown in black on most platforms. Previously displayed as a blue ribbon on Samsung devices. Similar to the Double Curly Loop but with only a single loop.

Title: Double Curly Loop
Description: Two curly loops, which represent a reel-to-reel tape recorder. Used as a symbol for voicemail on many phones. A variation of this logo is used by Free Dial , a toll-free telephone number by NTT in Japan.

Title: Part Alternation Mark
Description: Used in traditional Japanese music such as Noh or Renga , to indicate the start of a song. More specifically, the part alternation mark is displayed where the singer’s part begins. This symbol looks sort of like a lopsided capital M; or a rollercoaster track showing a dip, and then a drop off to the right.

Title: Eight-Spoked Asterisk
Description: Used in a similar manner to a regular * asterisk character but tends to be shown in a similar vertical alignment to a • bullet point. The eight spoked asterisk has both a ✳︎ text and ✳️ emoji presentation available on most platforms.

Title: Eight-Pointed Star
Description: A star with eight points, that is commonly shown in orange, and for some reason, with only four points. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Title: Sparkle
Description: Often used as a decorative bullet-point, the sparkle has both a ❇︎ text and ❇️ emoji presentation available on most platforms. Like with the ✨ Sparkles emoji, an icon similar to the four-point star design used to represent this emoji by several vendors (e.g. Apple, Microsoft) is often used within tech platforms to represent a feature that utilizes artificial intelligence.

Title: Copyright
Description: A copyright symbol, a circled capital letter C for copyright.

Title: Registered
Description: A registered trademark symbol, a circled capital letter R for registered.

Title: Chequered Flag
Description: A flag with black and white squares shown in a checkerboard pattern. Used to signal the start or end of a motor car race, though most often used to indicate that the first vehicle within a race has crossed the finish line.

Title: Triangular Flag
Description: A triangular red flag on a post. Most commonly associated with golf , as shown in the flag in hole emoji . Can also be used to represent the term red flag , signaling a problem or issue.

Title: Crossed Flags
Description: Two Japanese Flags , crossed at the base. Except on some older Samsung devices, which have previously displayed two South Korean flags , and on recent Huawei devices, where both flags are plain white .

Title: Black Flag
Description: A black-colored flag, shown waving on a post.

Title: White Flag
Description: A white flag, most often shown waving on a post. Traditionally used as a sign of surrender, the meaning of this flag as an emoji is less defined.

Title: Rainbow Flag
Description: A flag with six colors of the rainbow, generally including red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple. Commonly used by the LGBT movement as a gay pride flag , or simply pride flag and seen at Pride events . In February 2019 misinformation was spread about a so-called "anti-lgbt emoji" which can be created using a combining character to show a black and white glyph like 🚫 on top of the rainbow flag . This is possible with any emoji on supported platforms, in the same way keycaps are combining characters.

Title: Transgender Flag
Description: A flag with horizontal pale blue and pale pink stripes with a single white stripe in the middle, used as a Transgender or Transgender Pride flag and commonly seen at Pride events .

Title: Pirate Flag
Description: A skull and crossbones displayed on a black flag, used on pirate ships, also known as a Jolly Roger .

Title: Flag: United Nations
Description: The flag for United Nations. May show as the letters UN . This two letter regional indicator pair is an exceptional reservation as part of ISO 3166 .

Title: Flag: Angola
Description: The flag for Angola, which may show as the letters A and O on some platforms.

Title: Flag: Honduras
Description: The flag for Honduras, which may show as the letters HN on some platforms. While a 1949 decree specified that the flag’s stripes should be cyan, in practice they remained dark blue for nearly seventy years, until 2022. As of December 2024, most major vendors display the emoji’s stripes in a shade of blue darker than cyan.

Title: Flag: Martinique

Many platforms display the historical snake flag of Martinique instead of the Flag For France , which is the official flag of Martinique. As of 2024, the newer Ipséité flag is used by Apple, Google, and Samsung.

However, as of December 2024, no major emoji vendor has adjusted their designs to reflect this change. It’s possible they may not do so at all, given that such a subtle alteration would be nearly indistinguishable at the typical small sizes in which emojis are displayed.

Title: Flag: Taiwan
Description: The flag for Taiwan (officially Republic of China ), which may show as the letters TW on some platforms. This Taiwanese flag is hidden from the emoji keyboard on iOS devices when the region is set to China mainland or (as of iOS 13.1.2) Hong Kong or Macau. Chinese-model iPhones will not display this emoji and will instead show a missing character tofu (☒) in place of the flag, as will iOS devices with region set to China mainland . Hong Kong and Macua only hide this emoji from the emoji keyboard . This emoji is also not available within emoji set created by Chinese mobile manufacturer Huawei - it will render as a blank space.

Title: Flag: Switzerland
Description: The flag for Switzerland , which may show as the letters CH on some platforms. This flag is red, with a white cross in the center. Unlike most global flags, it is square instead of rectangular. Initially most vendors displayed this flag as a rectangle, consistent with other emoji flags, but today the majority of vendors display the flag with its accurate real-world shape.

Shown as either the Volcano + Sunbeams flag proposal by the Vexillological Association of Réunion , or the blue, white, red stripes + four colored quadrants proposal by the Association for the Réunion Flag . The Flag For France is the official flag of Réunion. All local flags used are unofficial.
